definition.value: A material entity which is clinically abnormal and part of an extended organism. Disorders are the physical basis of disease.

name: disorder
body: A material entity which is clinically abnormal and part of an extended organism. Disorders are the physical basis of disease.

definition.value: A cerebrovascular disorder is a disorder located in the vasculature of the brain.

children.name: cerebrovascular disorder
children.body: A cerebrovascular disorder is a disorder located in the vasculature of the brain.

definition.value: An ischemic stroke is caused by the lack of blood flow to part of the brain which then initiates the ischemic cascade and results in brain cell damage and infarction.

editor note.value: disorder. occurs when an artery to the brain is blocked.  The brain depends on its arteries to bring fresh blood from the heart and lungs. The blood carries oxygen and nutrients to the brain, and takes away carbon dioxide and cellular waste. If an artery is blocked, the brain cells (neurons) cannot make enough energy and will eventually stop working. If the artery remains blocked for more than a few minutes, the brain cells may die. The most common problem is narrowing of the arteries in the neck or head. This is most often caused by atherosclerosis, or gradual cholesterol deposition. If the arteries become too narrow, blood cells may collect and form blood clots. These blood clots can block the artery where they are formed (thrombosis), or can dislodge and become trapped in arteries closer to the brain (embolism). Another cause of  stroke is blood clots in the heart, which can occur as a result of irregular heartbeat (for example, atrial fibrillation), heart attack, or abnormalities of the heart valves. While these are the most common causes of ischemic stroke, there are many other possible causes. Examples include use of street drugs, traumatic injury to the blood vessels of the neck, or disorders of blood clotting. (http://www.strokecenter.org/patients/about-stroke/ischemic-stroke/)
The relationship of 'cerebral infarction' to 'ischemic stroke' is unknown.
The relationship of 'cerebral ischemia' to 'ischemic stroke' is unknown.

children.name: ischemic stroke
children.body: An ischemic stroke is caused by the lack of blood flow to part of the brain which then initiates the ischemic cascade and results in brain cell damage and infarction.

definition.value: A thrombotic stroke is an ischemic stroke that occurs when diseased or damaged cerebral arteries become blocked by the formation of a blood clot within the brain.

children.name: thrombotic stroke
children.body: A thrombotic stroke is an ischemic stroke that occurs when diseased or damaged cerebral arteries become blocked by the formation of a blood clot within the brain.

definition.value: Large-vessel thrombosis is a thrombotic stroke with physical basis in the larger blood-supplying arteries such as the carotid or middle cerebral artery.

editor note.value: look at Ropper/Brown; Pinciples of Neurology. 8th ed pp686 for more info

children.name: large-vessel thrombosis
children.body: Large-vessel thrombosis is a thrombotic stroke with physical basis in the larger blood-supplying arteries such as the carotid or middle cerebral artery.

definition.value: Small-vessel thrombosis is a thrombotic stroke with physical basis in one (or more) of the brain’s smaller, yet deeper, penetrating arteries such as the circle of willis,cerebellar arteries and basilar artery.

editor note.value: look at Ropper/Brown; Pinciples of Neurology. 8th ed pp686 for more info

children.name: small-vessel thrombosis
children.body: Small-vessel thrombosis is a thrombotic stroke with physical basis in one (or more) of the brain’s smaller, yet deeper, penetrating arteries such as the circle of willis,cerebellar arteries and basilar artery.

definition.value: An embolic stroke is an ischemic stroke that is caused by a embolus that forms somewhere other than the brain.

definition.value: A subarachnoid hemorrage is a hemorrhagic stroke that has physical basis on the surface of the brain and is caused by the rupture of an aneurysm and is the result of an artery on the surface of your brain bursting and spilling into the pia mater which is often charchterized by a sudden thunderclap headache and results in brain cell damage and infaraction. (may lead to vasospasm which may cause further cell damage via ischema)

term editor.value: Subarachnoid hemorrhage. In a subarachnoid hemorrhage, an artery on or near the surface of your brain bursts and spills into the space between the surface of your brain and your skull. This bleeding is often signaled by a sudden, severe headache. A subarachnoid hemorrhage is commonly caused by the rupture of an aneurysm, a small sack-shaped or berry-shaped outpouching on an artery in the brain. After the hemorrhage, the blood vessels in your brain may widen and narrow erratically (vasospasm), causing brain cell damage by further limiting blood flow to parts of your brain.

editor note.value: from Ropper/Brown; Pinciples of Neurology. 8th ed- look over

children.name: subarachnoid hemorrhage
children.body: A subarachnoid hemorrage is a hemorrhagic stroke that has physical basis on the surface of the brain and is caused by the rupture of an aneurysm and is the result of an artery on the surface of your brain bursting and spilling into the pia mater which is often charchterized by a sudden thunderclap headache and results in brain cell damage and infaraction. (may lead to vasospasm which may cause further cell damage via ischema)

definition.value: A disorder whose etiology involves (1) a modification to the patient's genomic DNA which leads to alterations in the normal expression pattern of the genome, but is (2) not a change in the nucleotide sequence.

children.name: epigenetic disorder
children.body: A disorder whose etiology involves (1) a modification to the patient's genomic DNA which leads to alterations in the normal expression pattern of the genome, but is (2) not a change in the nucleotide sequence.

definition.value: A disorder whose etiology involves an abnormality in the nucleotide sequence of an organism's genome.

children.name: genetic disorder
children.body: A disorder whose etiology involves an abnormality in the nucleotide sequence of an organism's genome.

definition.value: A genetic disorder acquired by a single cell in an organism that leads to a population of cells within the organism bearing the disorder.

children.name: acquired genetic disorder
children.body: A genetic disorder acquired by a single cell in an organism that leads to a population of cells within the organism bearing the disorder.

definition.value: A genetic disorder inherited during conception that is part of all cells in the organism.

children.name: constitutional genetic disorder
children.body: A genetic disorder inherited during conception that is part of all cells in the organism.

curator note.value:
Change entity URI

I had to move this term here in order to keep the reasoner (FaCT++) from telling me that 'normal pressure hydrocephalus' is equivalent to NOTHING.  This was due to the use of 'has material basis at all times', which has a domain/range restriction that limits it to material entities.

Alexander P. Cox

definition.value: A disorder which is the material basis of a neurologcal disease.

children.name: neurological disorder
children.body: A disorder which is the material basis of a neurologcal disease.

definition.value: A disorder that bears the disposition for an autoimmune demyelinating disease.

editor note.value: This may not be correct. It is possible that once we have the material bases for these diseases worked out, there may be no unifying property and the fact they are all neurolgical disorders will be inferred. But, for now, this class provides readability, organization and reasoning, etc.

children.name: autoimmune demyelinating disorder
children.body: A disorder that bears the disposition for an autoimmune demyelinating disease.

definition.value: A disorder that involves some structural damage that is immediately caused by a catastrophic external force.

editor note.value:
At the scale of organism (as opposed to the cellular scale or the population scale), an injury is typically the result of a catastrophic event. Consider the implications of making 'injury' a subtype of 'disorder'.

Note: Adopted subtype of disorder, and injury can occur at the scale of organism down to cellular level.

children.name: injury
children.body: A disorder that involves some structural damage that is immediately caused by a catastrophic external force.

definition.value: An infection that is clinically abnormal.

children.name: infectious disorder
children.body: An infection that is clinically abnormal.

definition.value: A disorder of some macroscopic part of a tissue

children.name: tissue disorder
children.body: A disorder of some macroscopic part of a tissue

definition.value: A tissue disorder that has resulted from a dysregulation of cell proliferation leading to a net increase in mass

children.name: neoplasm
children.body: A tissue disorder that has resulted from a dysregulation of cell proliferation leading to a net increase in mass
